title: Literature Circles — Introduction and Role Assignment
description: Students learn the structure of literature circles, a collaborative reading approach where each member takes a specific role. They are introduced to five roles (Discussion Director, Word Wizard, Passage Picker, Connector, Illustrator) and practice each with a short text.
instructions:
1. Explain literature circles as collaborative reading groups.
2. Introduce the five roles and their responsibilities.
3. Model each role using a short story or text excerpt.
4. Assign roles for the first literature circle session.
5. Student practices their assigned role with a short text.
6. Discuss how roles will rotate each week.

slides.heading: Literature Circles
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to be doing: Literature Circles, which is a cool way to read and talk about books together as a team. Think of it like being part of a detective squad, but instead of solving mysteries, you're digging deep into stories and understanding them better.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare role cards describing each of the five literature circle roles. Select a short text (1-2 pages) for practicing the roles. Print role sheet templates for each role.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so for this activity, we need a few things. You'll need your writer's notebook to jot down ideas, and then we have these role cards that explain your special job in the group. We've also got a short story for practicing, and some sheets to help you organize your thoughts for your role.

slides.text: Literature circles are like book clubs with structure. Each member reads the same text but has a different job. This means everyone contributes something unique to the discussion. The five roles are: Discussion Director (creates questions), Word Wizard (finds interesting vocabulary), Passage Picker (selects important passages), Connector (connects the reading to real life or other texts), and Illustrator (creates a visual response).
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide explains that literature circles are like a book club where everyone has a specific job to do, making sure we all get the most out of our reading. It's like a team where each person has a superpower: one person asks questions, another finds cool words, someone else picks important parts, another connects the story to real life, and someone else draws what's happening.

slides.text: DISCUSSION DIRECTOR: Write 4-5 thoughtful questions about the reading. Include both 'right there' questions (answers are in the text) and 'think and search' questions (require inference). The best questions start with 'Why,' 'How,' or 'What if.' Avoid yes/no questions. Your job is to lead the group discussion using your questions.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, if you're the Discussion Director, your mission is to come up with about four or five really good questions about the story, some easy ones that have answers right in the text, and some tricky ones that make you think harder. Your questions should help get everyone talking and sharing their ideas.

slides.text: WORD WIZARD: Find 4-5 words that are important, unusual, interesting, or new. Record the word, the sentence it appears in, its definition, and why it matters to the text. PASSAGE PICKER: Select 2-3 passages that are important, surprising, well-written, or confusing. Be ready to read them aloud and explain why you chose them. CONNECTOR: Find 2-3 connections between the text and your life, other books, current events, or our studies.
slides.mascot_explanation: If you're the Word Wizard, you'll find four or five interesting words in the story, write them down, where you found them, what they mean, and why they're important. The Passage Picker will choose a couple of key parts from the story that they think are super interesting or well-written and explain why they picked them.

slides.text: ILLUSTRATOR: Create a visual response to the reading. This could be a key scene, a character map, a timeline, a diagram, or a symbolic image. The illustration must connect to the text's meaning, not just show a random scene. Be ready to explain your artistic choices to the group.
slides.mascot_explanation: And if you're the Illustrator, you get to draw something from the story – maybe a cool scene, a character, or even a feeling – and then explain why you drew it that way. It's your chance to show what the story looks like in your mind and connect it to the main ideas.

slides.prompt: Read the short practice text. Then complete the role sheet for your assigned role. Discussion Director: Write 5 questions of varying depth. Word Wizard: Find 4 key words with definitions. Passage Picker: Select 2 important passages with explanations. Connector: Find 3 connections. Illustrator: Create a visual response. After everyone finishes, conduct a mini literature circle: share your work in order (Discussion Director leads, then others share, then discuss).
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to put it all together! You'll read the short story, then fill out the sheet for whatever role you were given, just like we practiced. After everyone has finished their part, we'll take turns sharing what we found and then have a short chat about the story, using all the cool work we just did.

slides.text: Literature circles give every reader a voice and a purpose. Roles rotate so you practice each skill over time. We will use literature circles throughout the year with our read-aloud books and independent reading. The goal is rich discussion where everyone contributes.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain the five literature circle roles, complete their assigned role sheet, and participate in a collaborative discussion?
slides.mascot_explanation: This whole literature circle thing is awesome because it makes sure everyone's voice is heard when we talk about books, and we'll keep doing it all year. By switching roles each time, you'll get to try out being a director, a word expert, and everything else, so you become a super well-rounded reader and discussion leader.

parent_notes: Literature circles develop reading comprehension, discussion skills, and collaboration. If you are homeschooling one child, you can take a role yourself or have the child rotate through multiple roles for the same text. The roles ensure engagement with the text from multiple angles — vocabulary, comprehension, analysis, connection, and creative response. This structure works with any book or text. Roles should rotate weekly so every child practices every skill.

title: Introduction to Fractions — Parts of a Whole Revisited
description: Students revisit fractions as parts of a whole, extending their understanding to include improper fractions and mixed numbers. They use fraction bars, number lines, and area models to build deep conceptual understanding before moving to operations.
instructions:
1. Review fraction vocabulary: numerator, denominator, proper fraction.
2. Introduce improper fractions (numerator greater than denominator).
3. Introduce mixed numbers and their relationship to improper fractions.
4. Practice converting between improper fractions and mixed numbers.
5. Represent fractions on number lines.
6. Order fractions with like denominators.

slides.heading: Fractions Revisited
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to learn about today: fractions! We're going to go back over what they are, but we'll also learn about two new kinds called improper fractions and mixed numbers.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare fraction bars showing halves, thirds, fourths, sixths, and eighths. Draw a large number line from 0 to 3 on the board or on paper.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide is showing us the tools we'll use for our fraction adventure. You've got fraction bars or circles, which are like puzzle pieces showing different parts of a whole. Your math journal is where you'll write everything down, and the number line helps us see where numbers live. Colored pencils and graph paper will help you draw things out, especially on the number line.

slides.text: A fraction represents part of a whole. The denominator (bottom) tells how many equal parts the whole is divided into. The numerator (top) tells how many parts we have. A proper fraction has a numerator less than the denominator: 3/4 means 3 out of 4 equal parts. But what if we have MORE parts than one whole?
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is a quick reminder that a fraction is just a piece of something whole. Think about a pizza: the bottom number, the denominator, tells you how many slices the whole pizza is cut into, and the top number, the numerator, tells you how many slices you actually have. So, 3/4 means you have 3 slices from a pizza cut into 4 equal slices.

slides.text: An IMPROPER fraction has a numerator equal to or greater than the denominator: 7/4 means 7 quarter-pieces. Since 4 quarters make a whole, 7/4 is one whole plus 3 extra quarters. A MIXED NUMBER combines a whole number and a fraction: 7/4 = 1 and 3/4. Both name the same amount — they are just different ways of writing it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're diving into improper fractions, which sound a little wild but are super useful. An improper fraction just means you have a "top" number that's bigger than or equal to the "bottom" number. So, 7/4 means you have 7 pieces, and each piece is a quarter of a whole. Since 4 quarters make a whole pizza, 7/4 is like one whole pizza plus 3 extra quarter slices. That's where mixed numbers come in – they just combine the whole part (1 pizza) with the leftover fraction part (3/4 of a pizza), so 7/4 is the same as 1 and 3/4.

slides.text: To convert an improper fraction to a mixed number: divide the numerator by the denominator. The quotient is the whole number, the remainder is the numerator, and the denominator stays the same. 11/3: 11 divided by 3 = 3 remainder 2, so 11/3 = 3 and 2/3. To convert a mixed number to an improper fraction: multiply the whole number by the denominator, add the numerator. 2 and 3/5: (2 x 5) + 3 = 13, so 2 and 3/5 = 13/5.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows you the secret code for switching between those two types of fractions. To go from an improper fraction to a mixed number, you just divide the top number by the bottom number – the answer you get is the whole part, and any leftovers become the new top number. To go the other way, from a mixed number to an improper fraction, you multiply the whole number by the bottom number and then add the original top number.

slides.text: On a number line, fractions fit between whole numbers. Divide each section between whole numbers into equal parts matching the denominator. For fourths: divide each unit into 4 equal parts. Then 1/4, 2/4, 3/4, 4/4 (=1), 5/4 (=1 and 1/4), and so on. The number line shows clearly that improper fractions are just fractions greater than 1.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to use the number line to see how these fractions fit in. Imagine the number line is a road, and each whole number is a town. We're going to mark all the spots in between, dividing up the road between towns into equal sections based on the fraction's bottom number. You'll see how fractions like 5/4 or 7/4 are just points on the road *past* the "1 town," showing they're bigger than one whole.

slides.prompt: In your math journal: (A) Convert to mixed numbers: 9/4, 15/7, 22/5, 17/3, 31/6. (B) Convert to improper fractions: 2 and 1/3, 4 and 2/5, 3 and 5/8, 6 and 1/4. (C) Draw a number line from 0 to 3 and plot these fractions: 1/4, 3/4, 5/4, 7/4, 9/4, 11/4. Label each as both an improper fraction and a mixed number. (D) Order from least to greatest: 2 and 1/3, 7/3, 2 and 2/3, 5/3, 8/3.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to put your new skills to the test! Grab your math journal and get ready to do some converting. First, you'll change the improper fractions into mixed numbers, then do the opposite. After that, use your colored pencils to draw a number line and mark all those fractions, labeling them both ways. Finally, you'll put a list of fractions in order from smallest to largest.

slides.text: Fractions are numbers, just like whole numbers, and they live on the number line. Improper fractions and mixed numbers are two names for the same value. Being fluent at converting between them will make fraction operations much easier. Tomorrow we tackle equivalent fractions and comparing.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student convert between improper fractions and mixed numbers and represent both on a number line?
slides.mascot_explanation: We've officially explored fractions beyond just simple parts of a whole! You learned how improper fractions and mixed numbers are just two ways of saying the same thing, and you practiced switching between them and even showing them on a number line. This is a super important skill that will make tackling even trickier fraction problems way easier later on.

parent_notes: Fractions are consistently identified as the most challenging math concept for elementary students. The key is building conceptual understanding with concrete models (fraction bars, number lines) before moving to abstract procedures. If your child struggles, spend extra time with fraction bars — physically holding 7 quarter-pieces and seeing that they make one whole and three-quarters provides understanding that no algorithm can replace. The number line model is especially important because it shows fractions as numbers, not just parts of pizzas.

title: Ancient Egypt — The Nile and the Rise of Civilization
description: Students begin the Egypt unit by exploring how the Nile River shaped every aspect of Egyptian civilization. They compare the Nile's role to the Tigris and Euphrates in Mesopotamia and examine how geography determines the development of civilizations.
instructions:
1. Locate Egypt and the Nile River on a map.
2. Describe the Nile's annual flooding cycle and its effect on agriculture.
3. Explain why Herodotus called Egypt 'the gift of the Nile.'
4. Compare Egyptian and Mesopotamian river civilizations.
5. Introduce Upper and Lower Egypt and their eventual unification.
6. Begin an Egypt section in the history journal.
materials_needed: Images of the Nile and Egyptian landscape

slides.heading: Ancient Egypt
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of a book, introducing us to our new topic: Ancient Egypt. The main idea is that the Nile River was super important to how Egypt developed, so important that the title calls Egypt "The Gift of the Nile." It's setting the stage for everything we're about to learn about this amazing civilization.

slides.setup_instructions: Display a map of Egypt showing the Nile, the delta, Upper and Lower Egypt, and the surrounding desert. Have images of the Nile valley and desert landscape ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide tells us what stuff we'll need for our Egyptian adventure. We've got a world map to see where Egypt is, a history journal to write and draw in, pictures of the Nile to get a feel for it, and colored pencils for our maps and drawings. Make sure you gather these up so you're ready to go!

slides.text: After studying Mesopotamia, we now travel southwest to another great river civilization. Egypt was built along the Nile, the world's longest river at 4,130 miles. The Greek historian Herodotus called Egypt 'the gift of the Nile,' and he was right — without the river, Egypt would be nothing but desert. Find the Nile on your map and trace it from south to north.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about finding Egypt and its famous river, the Nile, on our map. Think of the Nile like a giant highway that Ancient Egyptians used for everything – getting around, growing food, and even drinking. Your job is to find it on the map and then trace its path from the south all the way up to where it empties into the sea.

slides.text: Every summer, rains in central Africa caused the Nile to flood. Unlike the unpredictable floods of the Tigris and Euphrates, the Nile's floods were reliable and gentle. The water deposited rich black silt on the farmland, creating a narrow strip of incredibly fertile soil through the desert. Egyptians called their country 'Kemet' — the Black Land (for the dark soil) — and the desert 'Deshret' — the Red Land.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide explains how the Nile's flooding was actually a good thing for farming. Every year, the river would overflow and leave behind this super rich, dark soil called silt, kind of like leaving behind fertilizer. This created a really narrow, fertile strip of land perfect for growing crops, which is why they called their land "Kemet," the Black Land.

slides.text: The Nile shaped Egyptian life in every way. It provided water for farming, drinking, and bathing. It was the main highway — boats carried people and goods up and down the river. It supported fishing and papyrus (paper reed) growth. The desert on either side acted as a natural fortress, protecting Egypt from invaders. This security allowed Egyptian civilization to flourish relatively undisturbed for over 3,000 years.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're digging into *why* the Nile was so amazing. It wasn't just for farming; it was their main way to travel, gave them water for everything, and even helped grow the reeds they used to make paper! Plus, the deserts on either side acted like natural walls, keeping them safe and letting their civilization grow strong for thousands of years.

slides.text: Egypt was originally two kingdoms: Upper Egypt (southern, upstream) and Lower Egypt (northern, where the Nile fans into a delta). Around 3100 BCE, King Narmer (also called Menes) unified both kingdoms. He wore a double crown combining the white crown of Upper Egypt and the red crown of Lower Egypt. This unification marks the beginning of ancient Egyptian history as we know it.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a cool bit of history: Egypt wasn't always one big country. It started as two separate kingdoms, Upper and Lower Egypt, and this slide tells us how a king named Narmer brought them together for the first time. He even wore a special crown that combined symbols from both kingdoms, showing they were now united.

slides.prompt: In your history journal: (1) Draw a detailed map of Egypt showing the Nile, the delta, Upper Egypt, Lower Egypt, the Mediterranean Sea, the Red Sea, and the surrounding desert. Color the fertile Nile valley green, the desert tan, and water blue. (2) Create a comparison chart: Mesopotamia vs. Egypt. Compare: rivers, flooding patterns, natural protection, writing system, and government. (3) Write a paragraph explaining why Herodotus was right to call Egypt 'the gift of the Nile.' Use at least 3 specific examples.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to get creative! In your journal, you'll first draw a map of Egypt, coloring in the fertile green land along the Nile and the tan desert. Then, you'll make a chart comparing Egypt and Mesopotamia, thinking about their rivers and how safe they were. Finally, write a few sentences explaining why the Nile was such a great "gift" to Egypt, using examples from what we've learned.

slides.text: Egypt's story begins with geography. The Nile provided everything: water, food, transportation, protection, and the rich soil that supported one of humanity's greatest civilizations. Unlike Mesopotamia, which was constantly invaded, Egypt's desert barriers allowed a remarkably stable civilization to develop over three millennia. Next we explore the people who built this civilization — the pharaohs, priests, and ordinary Egyptians.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain how the Nile River shaped Egyptian civilization and compare the geographic advantages of Egypt and Mesopotamia?
slides.mascot_explanation: So, we've learned that Egypt's whole story really kicked off because of the Nile River, which gave them water, food, and protection, helping them build an amazing civilization. Unlike Mesopotamia, which had a tougher time with invasions, Egypt's natural defenses allowed it to thrive for a super long time. Now we're going to learn about the people who lived there!

parent_notes: The Egypt unit is one of the most engaging history units for this age group. The comparison with Mesopotamia builds analytical thinking — children see that geography shapes civilization in predictable ways. The key concept is environmental determinism: the physical environment significantly influences how civilizations develop. The map activity reinforces geography skills from the geography unit. If possible, show a satellite image of Egypt — the green Nile valley cutting through brown desert is striking and makes the concept immediately visual.

title: Physical Geography — Landforms of the Continents
description: Students explore major landform types (mountains, plateaus, plains, valleys, peninsulas, islands) and locate the most significant examples on each continent. They build a landform vocabulary and begin understanding how landforms shape human settlement.
instructions:
1. Review physical maps and how they show elevation.
2. Define major landform types with examples.
3. Tour each continent's major landforms using a physical map.
4. Discuss how landforms affect human settlement and culture.
5. Create a landform reference page with illustrations.
6. Begin a continent-by-continent landform study.

slides.heading: Shaping the Earth
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're about to learn: how the Earth's surface is shaped into all sorts of cool features, like mountains and valleys, and where we can find the biggest ones on each continent. Think of it like the title page of an adventure book about our planet!

slides.setup_instructions: Display a physical world map showing elevation through color. Have an atlas available for closer examination of each continent. Prepare simple illustrations or photos of each landform type.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is telling us what we need to get ready. We've got a physical world map that uses colors to show how high or low the land is – like green for low areas and brown for mountains. An atlas is like a super detailed book of maps, a geography journal is where we'll write and draw, and colored pencils will help us make our maps look awesome. Go grab these things with a grown-up!

slides.text: The Earth's surface is sculpted into an incredible variety of shapes called landforms. Mountains tower to over 29,000 feet. Plains stretch flat for thousands of miles. Valleys cut deep into the earth. Understanding landforms helps us understand why people live where they do, how they travel, and what resources they have.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is telling us that the Earth's surface isn't smooth; it's got all these different shapes called landforms, and they can be super tall like mountains or really flat like plains. Understanding these shapes is important because they help explain why people decided to build cities in certain places, how they get around, and what cool stuff they have access to.

slides.text: Key landform types: MOUNTAIN — elevated land rising steeply, usually over 2,000 feet above surroundings. PLATEAU — elevated flat land (like a table). PLAIN — low, flat land, often used for farming. VALLEY — low land between mountains or hills, often with a river. PENINSULA — land surrounded by water on three sides. ISLAND — land completely surrounded by water. DELTA — fan-shaped land at a river's mouth, built from deposited sediment.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we're learning the names and what these main landforms actually look like. A mountain is a big, steep hill, a plateau is like a flat-topped mountain, and a plain is just a large, flat area, often great for growing food. A valley is a low spot between hills or mountains, a peninsula sticks out into the water on three sides, and an island is all water around it. A delta is a triangle-shaped spot where a river meets the sea, made of dirt the river carried.

slides.text: Every continent has distinctive landforms. North America: Rocky Mountains, Great Plains, Appalachian Mountains. South America: Andes Mountains, Amazon Basin. Europe: Alps, Great European Plain. Africa: Sahara Desert, Great Rift Valley, plateaus. Asia: Himalayas (world's tallest), Siberian Plain. Australia: Great Dividing Range, vast interior plains. Antarctica: ice-covered plateau.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to see some of the most famous landforms on each continent. We'll look at places like the Rocky Mountains in North America, the huge Sahara Desert in Africa, and the super tall Himalayas in Asia. It's like a quick tour to see where these different landforms are located around the world.

slides.text: Landforms shape human life. Mountains create barriers that isolate communities and create different cultures on each side. Plains invite farming and large settlements. Rivers in valleys become trade routes. Peninsulas develop strong naval traditions. Deltas support dense populations because of rich soil. The ancient civilizations we are studying all grew in river valleys and plains — flat, fertile land near water.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide explains how these landforms really affect people's lives. For example, big mountain ranges can make it hard for people to travel between places, leading to different ways of life. Flat plains are perfect for growing lots of food and building big towns, and people often settled in river valleys because water was nearby for drinking and farming.

slides.prompt: In your geography journal, create a 'Landform Reference Guide.' For each of the 7 landform types (mountain, plateau, plain, valley, peninsula, island, delta): draw a simple cross-section or bird's-eye illustration, write a definition, and give one real-world example with its location. Then choose one continent and create a physical feature map showing at least 5 major landforms, labeled and color-coded by type.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to make our own landform guide! In your journal, draw what each landform looks like, write down its definition, and give an example of where it is on Earth. Then, pick one continent and draw a map of it, showing at least five of its major landforms and labeling them with different colors.

slides.text: Landforms are the stage on which human history plays out. Mountains, plains, valleys, and coasts determine where people settle, how they travel, and what they eat. As we study ancient civilizations, notice how their geography shaped their development. Next lesson we will zoom in on how these landforms were created.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student define 7 major landform types, give examples from different continents, and explain how landforms influence human settlement?
slides.mascot_explanation: We've learned so much about how the Earth's shapes, called landforms, really matter! They influence where people live, how they travel, and even what they eat, which is super important when we study how ancient civilizations grew up. Next time, we'll find out how these amazing landforms were actually made.

parent_notes: This lesson builds a vocabulary that will be used throughout the year in both geography and history. Physical maps can seem abstract — if possible, use a relief globe or a 3D topographic model alongside flat maps. The key insight for this age group is the connection between geography and history: civilizations do not arise randomly but in response to geographic conditions. When studying any civilization, always start by asking 'What was the geography like?' The landform reference guide becomes a valuable resource for the rest of the year.

title: The Lightning Thief — Chapters 1-2: Percy Jackson's Unusual Life
description: Students begin reading 'The Lightning Thief' by Rick Riordan, meeting Percy Jackson as he navigates life with ADHD and dyslexia at a boarding school. They discuss how mythology connects to the modern world and make predictions about the fantasy elements to come.
instructions:
1. Introduce the book and author Rick Riordan.
2. Discuss what students know about Greek mythology.
3. Read chapters 1-2 aloud together.
4. Discuss Percy's character: his struggles, strengths, and voice.
5. Analyze the first-person narrative perspective.
6. Connect to upcoming history studies of ancient Greece.
materials_needed: The Lightning Thief by Rick Riordan

slides.heading: The Lightning Thief
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the title slide for the book we're starting today, "The Lightning Thief" by Rick Riordan. It tells us we'll be reading the first two chapters, where we'll meet the main character, Percy Jackson, and get to know his interesting life.

items: The Lightning Thief by Rick Riordan
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. This is a good moment to preview Greek mythology connections that will appear throughout the book and in the history curriculum.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this part, we need a few things to get started. First, obviously, is the book "The Lightning Thief" itself. Then, you'll need a reading journal – that's just a notebook where you can write down your thoughts – and a pencil to write with. Having these ready will make sure we can jump right into the story and keep track of everything.

slides.text: Rick Riordan was a middle school English teacher in Texas who created the Percy Jackson character to tell his own son bedtime stories. His son had ADHD and dyslexia, and Riordan wanted him to see a hero who shared those traits. The result was one of the most popular book series of the 21st century — and a brilliant gateway to Greek mythology.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about the author, Rick Riordan. He used to be a teacher, and he actually came up with Percy Jackson because he wanted to tell his son stories. His son had some challenges like ADHD and dyslexia, and Rick wanted him to see a hero who was like him, which is pretty cool.

slides.text: As we read, you will encounter characters and creatures from Greek mythology — the same myths we will study when we reach ancient Greece in history. Percy Jackson's world imagines that all the Greek gods and monsters are real and still active in modern America. Pay attention to the mythological references — you will meet them again in history class.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready, because this book is packed with stuff from Greek mythology! You know, like the gods and monsters we'll learn about later in history class? Well, in this story, Riordan imagines that all those ancient myths are real and happening right now in modern America. So, keep an eye out for them; it’ll make history class way more interesting.

slides.text: Read chapters 1-2 aloud together. Notice Percy's narrative voice — he is funny, self-deprecating, and honest. He tells us he is a troubled kid who has been expelled from multiple schools. But as readers, we begin to see that Percy's 'problems' might actually be something else entirely. What clues does Riordan give us?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to the fun part: reading! We're going to read the first two chapters together. As we read, try to get a feel for Percy's voice – he's really funny and honest about himself, even admitting he's gotten kicked out of schools. But also listen for clues about why things might be happening to him.

slides.text: Percy narrates in first person — he tells his own story using 'I.' This gives us direct access to his thoughts and feelings, but it also means we only know what Percy knows. He is confused about the strange things happening around him, and so are we. This is a deliberate choice by Riordan to build mystery and identification with the character.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide explains how Percy tells his own story using "I," which is called first-person narration. It's like he's talking directly to you, sharing exactly what he's thinking and feeling. This is great because we really get to know him, but it also means we only know what he knows, and he's pretty confused about a lot of things himself.

slides.prompt: In your reading journal: (1) Create a character profile for Percy Jackson: his age, personality traits (at least 5), challenges he faces, and what makes him different. Use specific evidence from chapters 1-2. (2) List any mythological references you noticed (people, places, or events that seem connected to Greek myths). Even guesses count. (3) The chapter titles are hints about what will happen. Based on the title of chapter 1 and the events so far, write 3 predictions about what you think will happen in this book. (4) How does Percy's first-person narration affect your experience as a reader?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to do some detective work in your reading journal. First, create a profile for Percy, listing at least five personality traits and any challenges he's dealing with, using examples from the book. Then, jot down any Greek mythology stuff you spotted, even if you're just guessing. Finally, look at the title of chapter one and what we've read so far, and make three predictions about what you think will happen next in the story.

slides.text: Percy Jackson is a hero who does not yet know he is a hero. His ADHD and dyslexia, which seem like problems, may turn out to be signs of something extraordinary. As we continue reading, we will discover how Rick Riordan weaves ancient Greek mythology into a modern adventure. This book will make our study of ancient Greece much richer.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe Percy's character using textual evidence and explain how first-person narration affects the reading experience?
slides.mascot_explanation: So, we've learned that Percy is a hero in the making, and the things that seem like problems for him, like ADHD and dyslexia, might actually be special powers in disguise. Rick Riordan is a master at mixing ancient myths with modern adventures, and this book is going to make learning about ancient Greece way more exciting.

parent_notes: The Lightning Thief is phenomenally popular with 9-12 year olds, and for good reason — it is funny, fast-paced, and deeply engaging. It also brilliantly introduces Greek mythology in a way that sticks. The representation of ADHD and dyslexia as signs of being a demigod (rather than disabilities) is meaningful for many children. Riordan has said he wrote the series so that 'kids who are different can see themselves as heroes.' This book pairs perfectly with the upcoming history unit on ancient Greece. Let your child read ahead if they want to — enthusiasm for reading should never be restricted.

title: Vocabulary from Latin Roots — Duct, Rupt, Struct
description: Students study three Latin roots related to building and breaking: duct (lead), rupt (break), and struct (build). They discover how these roots appear in everyday, scientific, and academic vocabulary, and practice using root analysis to decode unfamiliar words.
instructions:
1. Review previously learned roots (port, scrib, dict, graph, phon, scope).
2. Study 'duct' (lead): conduct, produce, deduce, introduce, aqueduct.
3. Study 'rupt' (break): erupt, interrupt, corrupt, bankrupt, abrupt.
4. Study 'struct' (build): construct, structure, instruct, destruct, obstruct.
5. Practice combining roots with prefixes to decode words.
6. Word family challenge: find as many words as possible for each root.

slides.heading: Latin Roots — Building and Breaking
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure today. It's showing us we're going to dive into some super important word parts, called Latin roots, that are all about building things up and breaking things down. Think of it as getting ready to unlock a secret code for lots of words!

slides.setup_instructions: Update the growing root chart with today's three new roots. Have index cards ready for vocabulary card creation.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide tells us what tools we'll need for our word-building mission. You'll need your writer's notebook to jot down ideas, a root reference chart to keep track of all the word parts we're learning, a dictionary to look up anything tricky, and some index cards for making cool vocabulary flashcards. Make sure you have all these ready to go, and ask a grown-up if you need help finding them!

slides.text: Today we add three more Latin roots to our growing collection. These roots are about leading, breaking, and building — fundamental human actions. After today, you will have nine roots in your toolkit, enough to decode hundreds of English words. Let us begin with duct.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like our starting line! It's telling us we're adding three brand-new Latin roots to our collection today, and these ones are all about leading, breaking, and building. Knowing these three roots will help us understand tons of new words, kind of like collecting new superpowers for your brain! Let's get ready to focus on 'duct' first.

slides.text: DUCT means 'to lead.' Con + duct = conduct: to lead together (managing a group or leading electricity). Pro + duce = produce: to lead forward (bring into existence). De + duce = deduce: to lead away from (figure out by reasoning). Intro + duce = introduce: to lead into (bring someone in). Aque + duct = aqueduct: a structure that leads water.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, so 'duct' is our first root, and it means 'to lead.' See how the words on the slide use 'duct' to show leading? Like 'conduct' means to lead people together, and an 'aqueduct' is a channel that leads water. We're going to look at how adding different prefixes, like 'con-' or 'a-,' changes the meaning just a little bit but still keeps that 'lead' idea.

slides.text: RUPT means 'to break.' E + rupt = erupt: to break out (a volcano erupts). Inter + rupt = interrupt: to break between (break into someone's speech). Cor + rupt = corrupt: completely broken (morally broken). Bank + rupt = bankrupt: broken bench (in old Italy, a moneylender whose bench was broken could not do business). Ab + rupt = abrupt: broken off (sudden, unexpected).
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're looking at the root 'rupt,' which means 'to break.' Think about a volcano *erupting* – it's breaking out! When you *interrupt* someone, you break into their conversation. We'll see how 'rupt' helps us understand words about things breaking, shattering, or even failing, like going *bankrupt*.

slides.text: STRUCT means 'to build.' Con + struct = construct: to build together. In + struct = instruct: to build into (build knowledge into someone's mind). De + struct = destruct: to un-build (destroy). Ob + struct = obstruct: to build against (block). Infra + struct + ure = infrastructure: the built-in structures below (roads, bridges, pipes that support a city).
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide introduces our third root, 'struct,' which means 'to build.' When you *construct* a building, you're building it. When someone *instructs* you, they are building knowledge into your mind. We'll explore how 'struct' helps us understand words about creating, arranging, or even blocking things.

slides.prompt: Create vocabulary cards for 4 words from each root (12 total). For each card: the word on front; root meaning, prefix meaning, your definition, and a sentence on back. Then tackle the challenge: (1) What does 'restructure' mean? Break it into parts. (2) If 'in-' means 'not,' what does 'indestructible' mean? (3) The word 'disrupt' combines 'dis-' (apart) with 'rupt' (break). What does it mean, and how is it different from 'interrupt'? (4) Create a word that combines two roots you have learned (like 'phonograph'). Define your invention.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to get creative! You'll make flashcards for words using 'duct,' 'rupt,' and 'struct,' putting the word on one side and its meaning, prefix, and a sentence on the other. Then, you'll tackle some fun puzzles using the roots we've learned – try to figure out what 'restructure' or 'indestructible' means by breaking them down!

slides.text: You now have nine roots in your vocabulary toolkit — six Latin and three Greek. You can decode words related to carrying, writing, speaking, drawing, sound, seeing, leading, breaking, and building. That covers a huge portion of academic vocabulary. Keep watching for these roots everywhere.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student define the roots duct, rupt, and struct, provide word examples for each, and use root analysis to decode unfamiliar compound words?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you've done it! You've added three powerful new roots – 'duct,' 'rupt,' and 'struct' – to your word-power toolkit, bringing your total to nine. You can now understand words about leading, breaking, and building, which is a huge part of understanding so many things in school and in life. You're becoming a word detective!

parent_notes: The root collection is growing and becoming increasingly powerful. Consider creating a physical 'root wall' at home where new roots are posted each week with example words. The challenge questions require students to combine prefix and root knowledge — this analytical skill transfers to all reading. The 'bankrupt' etymology is a great conversation starter about how words carry history. If your child enjoys etymology, the book 'Word Roots' by Learning Resources or the website 'etymonline.com' provide endless fascinating word histories.

title: Equivalent Fractions — Finding and Creating Them
description: Students deepen their understanding of equivalent fractions using the multiplication and division principles. They practice generating equivalent fractions, simplifying to lowest terms using GCF, and verifying equivalence using cross-multiplication.
instructions:
1. Review what equivalent fractions mean (same value, different names).
2. The multiplication principle: multiply numerator and denominator by the same number.
3. The division principle: divide numerator and denominator by their GCF.
4. Introduce cross-multiplication as a check for equivalence.
5. Practice finding equivalent fractions and simplifying.
6. Apply to real-world situations.

slides.heading: Equivalent Fractions
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is all about equivalent fractions. Think of it like having a dollar bill versus four quarters – they're totally different things, but they're worth the same amount! Equivalent fractions are just different ways to write the same value, and we're going to learn how to find and make them.

slides.setup_instructions: Have fraction bars available for concrete verification. Display the GCF method from last week as reference.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this lesson, we'll need a few things. We've got these cool fraction bars that help us actually *see* if fractions are the same size, like building blocks. You'll also need your math journal and a pencil to write down your work, and some graph paper just in case we need to draw things out. Make sure you have these handy!

slides.text: Two fractions are equivalent when they represent the same amount. 1/2, 2/4, 3/6, 4/8 — all name the same value. Use your fraction bars to verify: line up a 1/2 bar with two 1/4 bars. They are the same length. But how do we find equivalent fractions without fraction bars?
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is explaining what equivalent fractions really mean. Imagine you have a pizza cut into two big slices, and then another pizza cut into four smaller slices. If you eat one slice from the first pizza (that's 1/2), it's the exact same amount of pizza as eating two slices from the second pizza (that's 2/4). We can use our fraction bars to line up a 1/2 piece and two 1/4 pieces to see they're the same length.

slides.text: The Multiplication Principle: Multiply both the numerator and denominator by the same non-zero number. This works because you are really multiplying by 1 (for example, 3/3 = 1). So 2/5 x 3/3 = 6/15. We have not changed the value — just renamed it. This principle lets you create infinitely many equivalent fractions for any fraction.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, this is a super useful trick called the Multiplication Principle. If you want to find a different way to write a fraction, you can multiply both the top number (numerator) and the bottom number (denominator) by the *same* number. It's like multiplying by one, so you don't actually change the fraction's value, just its name. For example, if we take 2/5 and multiply both by 3, we get 6/15, which is the same amount!

slides.text: Simplifying (or reducing) works the other way: divide both numerator and denominator by their GCF. Example: simplify 18/24. Find the GCF of 18 and 24. Factors of 18: 1,2,3,6,9,18. Factors of 24: 1,2,3,4,6,8,12,24. GCF = 6. So 18/24 = (18 divided by 6)/(24 divided by 6) = 3/4. A fraction is in simplest form when the GCF of numerator and denominator is 1.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part teaches us how to simplify fractions, which is like finding the simplest name for a fraction. We do this by dividing both the top and bottom numbers by their Greatest Common Factor (GCF), which is the biggest number that can divide into both of them. So, if we have 18/24, the biggest number that divides into both 18 and 24 is 6. When we divide both by 6, we get 3/4, which is the simplest way to write it.

slides.text: Cross-multiplication is a quick check for equivalence. To test if 3/4 = 9/12, cross multiply: 3 x 12 = 36 and 4 x 9 = 36. The cross products are equal, so the fractions are equivalent. If 2/3 and 5/8: 2 x 8 = 16 and 3 x 5 = 15. Not equal, so the fractions are not equivalent. This technique will also help us compare fractions.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's a really neat trick called cross-multiplication that lets you quickly check if two fractions are equal. You take the top number of the first fraction and multiply it by the bottom number of the second fraction, and then do the same thing the other way around: top of the second times the bottom of the first. If those two answers are the same, then the fractions are equivalent, just like checking if 3/4 and 9/12 are equal by doing 3x12 and 4x9.

slides.prompt: In your math journal: (A) Find 3 equivalent fractions for each: 2/3, 5/6, 4/7, 3/10. (B) Simplify to lowest terms using GCF: 12/16, 15/25, 24/36, 14/21, 30/45, 8/20. Show your GCF work. (C) Use cross-multiplication to determine if these pairs are equivalent: 3/5 and 12/20; 4/7 and 8/15; 6/9 and 10/15. (D) A recipe calls for 3/4 cup of sugar. You want to make half the recipe. What fraction of a cup do you need? Express your answer in simplest form.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to put all those cool tricks to work! In your math journal, you'll find some fractions and you need to create three new equivalent ones for each. Then, you'll simplify a list of fractions down to their simplest form, showing your GCF work. After that, you'll use cross-multiplication to see if certain pairs of fractions are equivalent. Finally, there's a recipe problem where you need to figure out how much sugar you need for half the recipe and write it in simplest form. You've got this!

slides.text: Equivalent fractions are the key to almost everything we will do with fractions: comparing, adding, subtracting, and simplifying answers. The GCF method for simplifying and the multiplication method for generating equivalents are tools you will use every day in math. Tomorrow we tackle comparing and ordering fractions.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student generate equivalent fractions, simplify to lowest terms using GCF, and verify equivalence using cross-multiplication?
slides.mascot_explanation: We just finished a ton of practice, and you've done a great job learning how to create and simplify fractions! You can now make new fractions that are the same value, shrink fractions down to their simplest names, and even check your work with cross-multiplication. These skills are super important because they're the building blocks for everything else we'll do with fractions, like adding and subtracting them.

parent_notes: Equivalent fractions are the most important fraction concept — if your child masters this, all fraction operations become much easier. The concrete models (fraction bars) should still be available for verification. The GCF connection to week 2 shows how math topics build on each other. If your child struggles with simplifying, have them factor both the numerator and denominator and look for common factors visually. The recipe problem is a practical application — cooking with fractions is one of the most authentic real-world uses of this skill.

title: Introduction to Earth Science — Rocks and Minerals Overview
description: Students begin the earth science unit by exploring the difference between rocks and minerals. They learn the definition of a mineral (naturally occurring, inorganic, solid, definite chemical composition, crystal structure) and begin classifying rock samples.
instructions:
1. Transition from scientific method to earth science content.
2. Define mineral and its five characteristics.
3. Define rock as a combination of minerals.
4. Show examples of common minerals: quartz, feldspar, mica, calcite.
5. Introduce the three rock types: igneous, sedimentary, metamorphic.
6. Begin observing and classifying rock samples.
materials_needed: Rock and mineral samples (or high-quality images)
Penny and glass plate (for hardness testing)

slides.heading: Rocks and Minerals
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of a cool book about what the Earth is made of. It tells us we're going to learn about rocks and minerals, which are basically the super important ingredients that make up everything on our planet, from mountains to the ground you walk on.

slides.setup_instructions: Gather a collection of rocks and minerals. Even 5-6 different samples are sufficient. If samples are unavailable, use high-quality printed images. Set up observation stations with magnifying glasses.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so for this part, we need to get our supplies ready. You'll need the rock and mineral samples – these are what we'll be looking at closely. Your science journal is where you'll write down what you discover, like a detective. The magnifying glass helps you see tiny details, the identification chart is like a clue book for figuring out what's what, and the penny and glass plate are for testing how tough the minerals are. Ask a grown-up to help you gather all these things.

slides.text: We now begin studying the Earth itself — what it is made of, how it works, and how it changes. Earth science starts with the solid ground beneath your feet. That ground is made of rocks, and rocks are made of minerals. Understanding rocks and minerals is understanding the very substance of our planet.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this step is like the introduction to our mission. We're shifting gears from how scientists do experiments to learning about the Earth itself. Think about it – everything solid around us, like sidewalks, buildings, and even sand, started out as rocks and minerals. Understanding these is key to understanding our whole planet!

slides.text: A MINERAL must meet five criteria: (1) Naturally occurring — not made by humans. (2) Inorganic — not from living things. (3) Solid — not liquid or gas. (4) Definite chemical composition — a specific formula. (5) Crystal structure — atoms arranged in a regular pattern. Quartz (SiO2) meets all five criteria. Sugar does not — it comes from plants (organic). Steel does not — it is manufactured.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is teaching us the official definition of a mineral. Imagine a mineral is like a super-pure ingredient. For something to be a mineral, it has to be found in nature (not made in a factory), not come from a living thing like a plant or animal, be solid, have a specific recipe (like a chemical formula), and have its tiny pieces arranged in a neat, organized pattern, kind of like LEGO bricks clicked together. Sugar or steel don't count because they don't meet all these rules.

slides.text: A ROCK is a natural solid made of one or more minerals. Granite, for example, is made of three minerals: quartz (clear or gray), feldspar (pink or white), and mica (shiny flakes). Rocks are classified by how they formed into three groups: IGNEOUS (from cooled magma or lava), SEDIMENTARY (from compressed layers of sediment), and METAMORPHIC (changed by heat and pressure). We will study each type in detail.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're talking about rocks! A rock is basically a mix of one or more minerals, kind of like a smoothie made of different fruits. Granite, for example, is a rock that has quartz, feldspar, and mica all mixed together. The slide also tells us there are three main ways rocks can form: by cooling hot lava (igneous), by getting squished together over time (sedimentary), or by being baked and squeezed by heat and pressure deep inside the Earth (metamorphic).

slides.text: Geologists identify minerals using observable properties: color (least reliable — many minerals come in multiple colors), luster (how it reflects light: metallic, glassy, dull), hardness (how easily it scratches), streak (the color of its powder when rubbed on a tile), and crystal shape. Mohs Hardness Scale ranks minerals from 1 (talc, softest) to 10 (diamond, hardest). A fingernail is about 2.5, a penny is 3.5, and glass is 5.5.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we become mineral detectives! We learn how to spot minerals by looking at their color (though that can be tricky!), how shiny they are (luster), how hard they are ��� we'll use our fingernails, a penny, and a piece of glass to test that – and the color of the powder they leave behind when you rub them on a special tile (that's called streak). There's even a scale to rank how hard they are, with diamonds being super hard and stuff like talcum powder being really soft.

slides.prompt: Observe and describe your rock and mineral samples. In your science journal, create a data table with columns: Sample Number, Color, Luster (metallic/glassy/dull/waxy/earthy), Hardness (test with fingernail, penny, and glass), Texture (rough/smooth/grainy/crystalline), and Other Observations. Make detailed qualitative and quantitative observations for each sample. Try to identify at least 2 samples using the mineral identification chart. For each one you identify, explain which properties helped you figure it out.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to be scientists! Grab your magnifying glass and your journal. For each rock and mineral sample you have, you're going to make notes about its color, how it looks shiny or not, how hard it is to scratch, and what it feels like. You'll use the penny and glass to help test the hardness. Then, try using the identification chart to see if you can figure out what at least two of them are, and write down which clues helped you solve the mystery!

slides.text: Rocks and minerals are the Earth's building blocks. Every mountain, canyon, beach, and cave is made of them. Over the next few weeks, we will explore how the three rock types form, how they transform through the rock cycle, and what they tell us about Earth's history. Start looking at rocks wherever you go — you will be amazed at the variety.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student define mineral using the five criteria, distinguish between rocks and minerals, and name the three rock types?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is us wrapping up our first look at rocks and minerals. Remember, they're the fundamental building blocks of everything you see outside – mountains, beaches, even the soil where plants grow. We'll be diving deeper into how these different kinds of rocks are made and change over time, so start paying attention to the rocks you see everywhere; you'll be surprised by how much variety there is!

parent_notes: This lesson is much more engaging with real rock and mineral samples. Inexpensive rock collections are available from educational supply stores, or you can collect rocks from your yard and neighborhood. Even a handful of different-looking rocks provides excellent observation practice. The hardness testing (scratching with a fingernail, penny, and glass) is hands-on science at its best. If you have access to a university or natural history museum, a visit to their geology collection would enrich this unit enormously. Children at this age often love collecting rocks — encourage it and help them identify their finds.

title: Egyptian Art — Hieroglyphs and the Rules of Egyptian Painting
description: Students explore the distinctive conventions of ancient Egyptian art: figures shown with head and legs in profile but torso facing forward, size indicating importance, and the use of hieroglyphs as both writing and art. They create an Egyptian-style wall painting.
instructions:
1. Connect to the Egypt history unit.
2. Show examples of Egyptian tomb paintings and explain their purpose.
3. Identify Egyptian artistic conventions: composite view, hierarchical proportion.
4. Introduce hieroglyphs as art and writing combined.
5. Students create an Egyptian-style painting using proper conventions.
6. Discuss why Egyptian art followed strict rules for 3,000 years.
materials_needed: Gold paint or yellow colored pencil

slides.heading: Art of Ancient Egypt
slides.subheading: Rules, Symbols, and Stories on the Wall
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into ancient Egyptian art. It's telling us we're going to learn about the special rules, the cool symbols, and the stories they used to paint on their walls. Think of it as setting the scene before we dive into the main story.

slides.setup_instructions: Display several examples of Egyptian tomb paintings showing the distinctive conventions. Print a simple hieroglyph chart with common symbols. Set up painting or drawing materials.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide lists everything we need to make our own Egyptian art. We've got pictures of real tomb paintings to look at, a chart with hieroglyph symbols (like ancient emojis!), big paper to draw on, paints or colored pencils, and a ruler. You'll need to gather these up, maybe with a grown-up's help, so we're ready to create.

slides.text: Egyptian art is instantly recognizable — and intentionally so. For over 3,000 years, Egyptian artists followed the same strict rules. This was not because they could not draw more realistically (Greek visitors proved they could learn other styles). They chose these conventions because their art served a spiritual purpose: tomb paintings were meant to magically provide for the dead in the afterlife.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we learn *why* Egyptian art looks so unique. For thousands of years, they drew things in a very specific way, not because they weren't good at drawing differently, but because their art had a magical job: to help people who had died live forever in the afterlife. It was like a special recipe for eternity!

slides.text: The COMPOSITE VIEW shows the human body from its most recognizable angles simultaneously: the head in profile (side view), the eye from the front, shoulders facing forward, and legs in profile. This was not a mistake — it was a deliberate choice to show each body part in its clearest form. HIERARCHICAL PROPORTION meant the most important person was drawn largest. The pharaoh towers over servants and enemies.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're diving into the specific tricks Egyptian artists used. See how the people have their heads and legs sideways, but their shoulders are facing us? That's called the "composite view," and they did it to show every part of the body as clearly as possible. Also, notice how the most important person is the biggest? That's "hierarchical proportion," and it was a way to show who was boss.

slides.text: Colors were symbolic: red-brown for men's skin, yellow-gold for women's skin, green for vegetation and rebirth, blue for the Nile and the sky, white for purity, black for fertile soil and the afterlife. Gold represented the flesh of the gods. Every color carried meaning, just as every figure's size and position told the viewer about their importance and role.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is all about colors and what they meant to the Egyptians. The skin color wasn't just random – red-brown for men, yellow for women, green for new life, blue for the sky and river, and gold for the gods themselves! Every color choice was deliberate and added to the meaning of the picture, just like the size of the people.

slides.text: HIEROGLYPHS (meaning 'sacred carvings') were both writing and art. Each hieroglyph was a tiny picture: an owl, a reed, a hand, a mouth. They could be read left to right, right to left, or top to bottom — you read toward the direction the animal figures face. Hieroglyphs were carved on temple walls, painted in tombs, and written on papyrus scrolls. They were so complex that only scribes could read them.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we learn about hieroglyphs, which are super cool because they're like tiny pictures that are also letters. They could mean a word or a sound, and Egyptians used them everywhere – on tombs, temples, and scrolls. You can even read them in different directions, usually toward the way the animal pictures are facing.

slides.prompt: Create an Egyptian-style wall painting on large paper. Follow the Egyptian rules: (1) Draw a horizontal register line (ground line) for figures to stand on. (2) Draw at least 2 human figures using the composite view (profile head, front shoulders, profile legs). Make one figure larger to show importance. (3) Use symbolic colors (if painting). (4) Add hieroglyphs around or above your figures — use the reference chart to spell your name or a short message. (5) Add Egyptian symbols: the ankh (life), the Eye of Horus (protection), or lotus flowers.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to make your own masterpiece! You'll draw a line for the ground, then draw at least two people using that composite view we learned about, making one bigger than the other. Use those symbolic colors if you're painting, and then grab your hieroglyph chart to add your name or a message. Don't forget to add some cool Egyptian symbols like the ankh for life!

slides.text: Egyptian art endured for millennia because it served a sacred purpose — every painting was a spell for eternal life. The rules ensured that the magic would work. When we look at Egyptian art, we are looking at one of humanity's most consistent and purposeful artistic traditions. Next we will explore Egyptian architecture — the pyramids.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify Egyptian artistic conventions (composite view, hierarchical proportion, symbolic color) and apply them to create an Egyptian-style painting?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide reminds us why Egyptian art lasted so long: it was all about making sure people had a magical, eternal life. Those strict rules weren't just for looks; they were essential for the spells in the paintings to work correctly. Pretty amazing that art could have such a powerful job, right?

parent_notes: Egyptian art conventions fascinate children, especially the 'why' behind the rules. The composite view is not a lack of skill but a choice — show your child a realistic Egyptian portrait (they exist from later periods) to prove Egyptians could draw realistically when they chose to. The hieroglyph name-writing activity is universally popular. Many online tools convert English names to hieroglyphs. The symbolic color system shows how art can carry meaning beyond representation — a concept that applies to all art, including modern advertising and film.

title: Study Skills — Active Reading Strategies
description: Students learn active reading strategies that transform passive reading into deep engagement with text. They practice SQ3R (Survey, Question, Read, Recite, Review) and annotation techniques that improve comprehension and retention across all subjects.
instructions:
1. Discuss the difference between passive reading and active reading.
2. Introduce the SQ3R method for reading textbooks and informational text.
3. Demonstrate annotation: underlining, margin notes, questions, connections.
4. Practice SQ3R with a short informational passage.
5. Practice annotation with a second passage.
6. Discuss which strategies work best for different types of reading.
materials_needed: Short informational text (2 copies — one for annotation)

slides.heading: Active Reading
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to learn about: active reading, which is like giving your brain a workout while you read so you actually remember stuff. It's about making reading more than just looking at words; it's about making it stick in your head.

slides.setup_instructions: Print two copies of a short informational passage (1-2 pages) on a topic the student is studying. One copy is for annotation practice. Have highlighters and sticky notes ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this part, we need a few things to get started. You'll need your notebook and pencils for writing down ideas, and then copies of some reading material – one to mark up and one to keep clean. We've also got highlighters to color-code important stuff and sticky notes for adding thoughts, so make sure you have all that ready!

slides.text: Have you ever read a whole page and then realized you have no idea what it said? That is passive reading — your eyes moved over the words, but your brain did not engage. Active reading means interacting with the text: asking questions, making connections, and monitoring your understanding. It takes more effort, but you learn much more.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, have you ever finished reading a page and felt like your brain was totally blank? That's called passive reading. Active reading is the opposite; it's when you're actually talking to the text in your head, asking questions, and thinking about what it means. It takes a little more effort, but you'll understand and remember so much more.

slides.text: SQ3R is a five-step active reading method: SURVEY: Before reading, scan the headings, bold words, images, and captions. Get the big picture. QUESTION: Turn each heading into a question. 'The Water Cycle' becomes 'What is the water cycle?' READ: Read to answer your questions. RECITE: After each section, say or write the main idea in your own words. REVIEW: After finishing, go back and check your understanding.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide breaks down a cool strategy called SQ3R, which is like a five-step plan to really dig into what you're reading. You'll first SURVEY the text to get the big picture, then QUESTION what the headings are asking, READ to find the answers, RECITE the main points out loud or in writing, and finally REVIEW everything to make sure it all makes sense.

slides.text: ANNOTATION means writing on or near the text as you read. Underline key ideas (not everything — just the most important points). Write brief margin notes summarizing each paragraph. Put a question mark next to confusing parts. Write connections: 'This reminds me of...' or 'This connects to our study of...' Star surprising or important facts. Annotation turns reading into a conversation with the author.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, this is about annotation, which is basically like having a conversation with the author right on the page. You'll underline the super important stuff, jot down short notes in the margins to summarize, put question marks by things you don't get, and maybe even write down connections to stuff you already know. It makes the text feel alive and helps you really think about it.

slides.text: Different reading requires different strategies. For textbooks and informational text: use SQ3R and annotation. For novels and literature: focus on connections, questions, and predictions. For math word problems: read twice, underline key information, circle what you are asked to find. The common thread is ENGAGEMENT — never let your mind go on autopilot while reading.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a helpful reminder that different kinds of reading need different approaches. For school stuff like textbooks, SQ3R and annotation are awesome tools. But for stories, you might focus more on what you think will happen next or how it makes you feel. The main idea is to always keep your brain switched on and involved.

slides.prompt: Practice both strategies: (1) Use SQ3R with the first text copy: Survey it for 2 minutes (note headings, bold words, images). Write 3 questions based on headings. Read to answer your questions. Recite the main ideas from memory. Review by checking your answers. (2) Use annotation on the second text copy: Underline key ideas, write margin notes, mark questions with ?, mark connections with C, and star important facts. Compare the two experiences. Which helped you understand the text better? Write a reflection paragraph about which strategies you will use going forward.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to try it out! You'll use the SQ3R method on one piece of reading, then use annotation on another, and then you'll think about which one helped you understand things better and write down which strategies you want to use more. Take your time and really focus on what works best for you.

slides.text: Active reading is one of the most important study skills you can develop. Students who read actively learn more, remember more, and perform better on tests — not because they are smarter, but because they engage more deeply with the material. Choose one strategy to use consistently this week and notice the difference.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student apply SQ3R and annotation strategies to informational text and explain how active reading improves comprehension?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is just wrapping things up, reminding us that active reading is a super powerful skill that helps you learn way more, not because you're a genius, but because you're actively engaging with the material. Pick just one strategy to really focus on this week and see how much it helps you understand your schoolwork better.

parent_notes: Active reading strategies are evidence-based methods for improving comprehension. The SQ3R method was developed by educational psychologist Francis Robinson in 1946 and remains one of the most effective reading strategies available. Annotation can be practiced on photocopies, or your child can use sticky notes in books they do not want to write in. The most important takeaway is that reading is not a passive activity — it requires mental effort. Model active reading yourself: when you read something interesting, share your thinking aloud ('I wonder why... This reminds me of... I did not expect...').

title: Advanced Grammar — Compound and Complex Sentences in Writing
description: Students apply their knowledge of clauses and sentence types to their own writing, focusing on creating compound sentences with coordinating conjunctions and complex sentences with subordinating conjunctions. They revise a piece of their writing for sentence variety.
instructions:
1. Review compound sentences (two independent clauses joined by FANBOYS).
2. Review complex sentences (independent + dependent clause).
3. Introduce compound-complex sentences.
4. Analyze sentence variety in a published passage.
5. Student revises a piece of their writing for sentence variety.
6. Count sentence types to check for balance.

slides.heading: Sentence Variety in Action
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title screen for our writing adventure today. It's telling us we're going to learn all about making our writing more interesting by using different kinds of sentences, like compound and complex ones, to make it sound really cool and professional.

slides.setup_instructions: Select a published passage (1-2 paragraphs) from a well-written book that demonstrates sentence variety. Have the student's essay or a previous writing piece ready for revision.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so for this activity, we'll need a few things to help us become sentence superheroes. Grab your writer's notebook – that's where we'll jot down notes. Then, find a piece of writing you've already done, maybe an essay or a story. We'll also need a short part from a published book that shows off good sentence variety, and some colored pencils to mark things up.

slides.text: COMPOUND sentences join two independent clauses with a coordinating conjunction (For, And, Nor, But, Or, Yet, So — FANBOYS) and a comma: 'The Nile flooded every year, and it deposited rich soil on the farmland.' Both parts could stand alone as sentences, but joining them shows a relationship.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is a quick reminder about compound sentences. Think of them as two complete thoughts, like two separate little sentences, that are best friends. We join them with a comma and a special connector word from the FANBOYS list (For, And, Nor, But, Or, Yet, So) to show how those two thoughts relate to each other.

slides.text: COMPLEX sentences join an independent clause with a dependent clause using a subordinating conjunction (because, when, although, if, while, since, after, before, unless, until): 'Because the Nile flooded reliably, Egyptian farmers could plan their crops.' The dependent clause cannot stand alone.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, this is about complex sentences. Imagine one complete thought (an independent clause) and another thought that's a bit incomplete on its own (a dependent clause). We connect these with words like "because," "when," or "if" to show a cause-and-effect or a time relationship, and the dependent part can't stand alone as a sentence.

slides.text: COMPOUND-COMPLEX sentences combine both: two or more independent clauses AND at least one dependent clause: 'When the Nile flooded, the farmers rejoiced, and they began planting their seeds.' This has a dependent clause ('When the Nile flooded'), and two independent clauses joined by 'and.' Use these sparingly — they add sophistication but can become confusing.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide introduces the super-sentence: the compound-complex! It's like mixing the last two types together, so you have at least two complete thoughts and at least one incomplete thought. They can make your writing sound really sophisticated, but the trick is to use them carefully so they don't get too confusing for your reader.

slides.text: Good writing has VARIETY. Read this published passage and count the sentence types. Notice how the author mixes short simple sentences (for impact), compound sentences (for connection), and complex sentences (for showing relationships). A paragraph of all simple sentences sounds choppy. A paragraph of all complex sentences sounds dense. The best writing varies the rhythm.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is super important for making your writing sound awesome! Good writers don't just use the same type of sentence over and over; they mix them up like a DJ mixing beats. This slide shows that using a variety of short, medium, and longer sentences creates a better rhythm that keeps readers hooked, instead of sounding boring or too complicated.

slides.prompt: Part 1: Analyze the published passage. Color-code each sentence: yellow for simple, blue for compound, green for complex, red for compound-complex. Count how many of each type the author uses. Part 2: Take a piece of your own writing (your essay, a journal entry, or the Day in the Life narrative from history). Color-code your sentences the same way. Do you see a pattern? Most students overuse simple sentences. Part 3: Revise your writing to improve variety. Combine at least 3 pairs of simple sentences into compound or complex sentences. Add at least one compound-complex sentence. Read the revised version aloud — does it flow better?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, here's where we put it all together! First, take that published passage and use your colored pencils to mark all the different sentence types we've learned – yellow for simple, blue for compound, green for complex, and red for compound-complex. Then, do the same thing with your own writing and see if you use too many of one type. Finally, revise your writing by combining some of those simple sentences into more interesting compound or complex ones, and read it out loud to hear how much better it sounds!

slides.text: Sentence variety is what separates good writing from great writing. Simple sentences hit hard. Compound sentences connect ideas. Complex sentences show relationships. The best writers blend all types in a rhythm that pulls the reader forward. From now on, check every piece of writing you produce for sentence variety.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify the four sentence types in published writing, analyze their own writing for sentence variety, and revise to improve the balance?
slides.mascot_explanation: So, we've learned how to use different sentence structures to make our writing way more engaging. We practiced identifying and creating compound, complex, and even compound-complex sentences, and saw how mixing them up creates a great flow. Now, you're ready to make sure all your writing has that awesome sentence variety!

parent_notes: Sentence variety is a concrete, measurable writing skill. The color-coding technique makes it visual — if your child's writing is all yellow (simple sentences), the issue is immediately obvious. When revising for variety, encourage your child to read aloud. The ear is an excellent tool for detecting monotonous rhythms. Published authors are excellent models — when reading together, occasionally pause to notice an especially effective sentence and discuss its structure. Gary Paulsen (author of Hatchet, which we will read later) is famous for his short, punchy sentences. Compare his style to longer, more flowing prose to see how sentence length creates different effects.

title: Comparing and Ordering Fractions — Unlike Denominators
description: Students learn to compare fractions with unlike denominators using three strategies: finding common denominators, using benchmark fractions (0, 1/2, 1), and cross-multiplication. They practice ordering sets of fractions from least to greatest.
instructions:
1. Review comparing fractions with like denominators (just compare numerators).
2. Strategy 1: Find a common denominator using LCM.
3. Strategy 2: Compare to benchmark fractions (0, 1/2, 1).
4. Strategy 3: Cross-multiplication for quick comparison.
5. Practice ordering sets of fractions.
6. Solve word problems involving fraction comparison.

slides.heading: Comparing Fractions
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our fraction adventure. It's introducing us to comparing fractions and asking the big question: "Which is larger?" Think of it like figuring out who has a bigger piece of cake or who ran farther in a race.

slides.setup_instructions: Have fraction bars available for concrete comparison. Draw a large number line from 0 to 2 on the board. Have the LCM method from week 2 available for reference.
